top_ideas.idea: Being and Time – The Question of Being
top_ideas.description: Heidegger’s main philosophical project was to revive the forgotten question of the meaning of Being itself—not a specific being, but Being as such. He argued that Western philosophy had long neglected this fundamental issue.
Heidegger’s term for human existence, Dasein ('being-there'), refers to the unique way humans are aware of and question their own Being. Dasein is always situated, temporal, and engaged in the world.
One of Heidegger’s central existential insights: authentic human life requires confronting our mortality. Awareness of death discloses our finitude and individuality, enabling authentic existence.

Most people live inauthentically, conforming to 'the They' (das Man)—the impersonal norms of society. Authenticity involves reclaiming one's own existence by facing the truth of one’s finitude and making meaningful choices.
Human beings are 'thrown' into a world they did not choose, into historical, cultural, and material contexts. Thrownness emphasizes our facticity—conditions we cannot escape but must respond to.

Care is the fundamental structure of Dasein's Being. It describes how we are always already involved with the world, concerned with possibilities, projects, and relationships—even before conscious reflection.

Time is not just a sequence of moments but the horizon within which Being is disclosed. Dasein exists in time through projection (future), thrownness (past), and presence (now), forming a unified temporal structure.
Being becomes intelligible in a 'clearing'—a metaphorical open space where beings can appear and be understood. Heidegger believed truth involves the 'unconcealment' of beings in this clearing.
key_books: The Origin of the Work of Art

top_ideas.description: Modern technology reveals the world only as a resource to be controlled and optimized. Heidegger called this 'enframing' and warned that it conceals deeper ways of Being, reducing existence to utility.
Later in life, Heidegger emphasized a 'turn' in his thinking—from the analysis of Dasein to the 'letting be' of Being. He moved toward a more poetic, meditative approach to truth and Being.

top_ideas.idea: Language as the House of Being
top_ideas.description: Heidegger famously wrote that 'language is the house of Being.' Language is not just a tool for communication, but the medium through which Being is revealed. Poetic language can disclose truths hidden by ordinary speech.
